articles.headline: Beneath Booming Cities, China’s Future Is Drying Up
articles.snippet: Groundwater levels are dropping around China, where leaders face tough choices as cities, industry and farming compete for an unbalanced and finite water supply.
articles.abstract: Groundwater levels are dropping around China, where leaders face tough choices as cities, industry and farming compete for an unbalanced and finite water supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIJIAZHUANG, China — Hundreds of feet below ground, the primary water source for this provincial capital of more than two million people is steadily running dry. The underground water table is sinking about four feet a year. Municipal wells have already drained two-thirds of the local groundwater.

articles.headline: Home Sales and Prices Fall Sharply
articles.snippet: Sales of new homes dropped to the slowest pace in over seven years, foreshadowing further economic trouble ahead.
articles.abstract: Sales of new homes dropped to the slowest pace in over seven years, foreshadowing further economic trouble ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of new homes plunged in August to their slowest pace in more than seven years as tighter credit and rising inventories continued to weigh down the housing industry. The grim statistics could foreshadow further economic weakness in the fourth quarter, analysts said.

articles.headline: Push for Action on Flight Delays
articles.snippet: President Bush ordered transportation officials to take steps to reduce delays in the nation’s airspace.
articles.abstract: President Bush ordered transportation officials to take steps to reduce delays in the nation’s airspace.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 — After the worst summer of airline delays on record, President Bush on Thursday ordered transportation officials to work with airline executives to reduce delays in the nation’s overcrowded airspaces, beginning in New York.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Jeff Bailey

articles.headline: Complaint Offers Window on Chinese Drug Ring
articles.snippet: An affidavit filed by an agent of the F.D.A. details the personal involvement of Jin Lei, the founder of one of China’s largest drug makers, in an illegal hormone distribution ring.
articles.abstract: An affidavit filed by an agent of the F.D.A. details the personal involvement of Jin Lei, the founder of one of China’s largest drug makers, in an illegal hormone distribution ring.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGCHUN, China Sept. 27 — The chief executive of a leading Chinese pharmaceutical company used e-mail aliases, offshore bank accounts and a network of drug traffickers to illegally distribute millions of dollars worth of human growth hormone in the United States, federal officials said in a criminal complaint, provided to The New York Times on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: I.M.F. Faces a Question of Identity
articles.snippet: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who was appointed to head the I.M.F., will inherit an organization struggling to find a purpose in a vastly changed financial world.
articles.abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who was appointed to head the I.M.F., will inherit an organization struggling to find a purpose in a vastly changed financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 — A decade ago, the International Monetary Fund helped to stabilize the world economy after markets collapsed in Latin America, Russia and Asia. Though critics often have rued its interventionism, the fund was widely hailed as a heroic guardian of the global financial system.

articles.headline: E.E.O.C. Files Lawsuit Against Bloomberg L.P.
articles.snippet: The lawsuit against the financial services company accuses it of discriminating against women.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit against the financial services company accuses it of discriminating against women.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government is suing Bloomberg L.P., the financial services and media giant founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, saying the company engaged in a pattern of discrimination against women after they became pregnant and took maternity leave.

articles.headline: Advocate of Paying Chiefs Well Revises Thinking
articles.snippet: Michael C. Jensen, an early advocate for paying corporate executives well, is calling for greater accountability for C.E.O.’s.
articles.abstract: Michael C. Jensen, an early advocate for paying corporate executives well, is calling for greater accountability for C.E.O.’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Michael C. Jensen was an early inventor of bigger-than-life compensation packages for corporate chief executives, and nearly 20 years later, he still believes passionately in the concept of “pay for performance” that he championed.

articles.headline: Stock Loans Are No Place for Secrecy
articles.snippet: Creating greater transparency in the stock loan market, relied upon by those who borrow stock to sell short, would help people get fairer prices.
articles.abstract: Creating greater transparency in the stock loan market, relied upon by those who borrow stock to sell short, would help people get fairer prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: An opaque market is a market that insiders love, simply because they can take advantage of outsiders. It is also a market that produces prices no one can be sure are trustworthy.

articles.headline: Blackwater Shooting Scene Was Chaotic
articles.snippet: Participants in a Baghdad security operation this month say that at least one guard continued firing on civilians while colleagues called for a cease-fire.
articles.abstract: Participants in a Baghdad security operation this month say that at least one guard continued firing on civilians while colleagues called for a cease-fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 27 — Participants in a contentious Baghdad security operation this month have told American investigators that during the operation at least one guard continued firing on civilians while colleagues urgently called for a cease-fire. At least one guard apparently also drew a weapon on a fellow guard who did not stop shooting, an American official said.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: More Deaths in Myanmar, and Defiance
articles.snippet: Violence began before dawn as Myanmar’s military junta tried to crush a wave of nationwide protests with tear gas, beatings and volleys of gunfire.
articles.abstract: Violence began before dawn as Myanmar’s military junta tried to crush a wave of nationwide protests with tear gas, beatings and volleys of gunfire.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Sept. 27  Brutality and defiance marked the second day of an armed crackdown in Myanmar on Thursday as the military junta tried to crush a wave of nationwide protests in the face of harsh international condemnation.
